Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/057
references.B61LIG01NAUS: Ligon, J.S. 1961. New Mexico birds and where to find them. The University of New Mexico Press, Albuquerque.

habitat_description:
The breeding habitat for this species occurs on isolated freshwater islands consisting of boreal forests, prairies, or high plains in large bodies of water (Andrews and Righter 1992, Knopf and Evans 2004). These isolated islands provide protection from mammalian predators (NatureServe and Andrews and Righter 1992).  Species basically nests in two ecological settings.  The first is on (sometimes large) islands in large lakes as at Gunnison Island in Great Salt Lake, Molly Islands in Yellowstone Lake and Anaho Island in Pyramid Lake.  At these sites, birds often fly 100km or more to outlying rivers, marshlands and ephemeral wetlands to forage.  In late summer, birds in these settings also may forage in deep lakes when sunning fish (especially carp, Cyprinus carpio,) are near the surface.  The second ecological setting is one of nesting on ephemeral islands in shallower wetlands as in the northern Great Plains or on the Texas coast.  The use of sparsely vegetated areas predominates in southern and dryer regions, grading to shrubs and trees in forested regions.  Nest sites and territories support little or no vegetation, but nests are commonly located adjacent to or interspersed within available cover, for example, alkali weed (Bassia), bluegrass (Poa), reeds (Phragmites), nettles (Urtica), and cinquefoil (Potentilla).  In forested regions, sometimes nest under trees, including poplars (Populus), spruce (Picea), fir (Abies) and willows (Salix).  Birds must walk from nest to forest edge before flying (Knopf and Evans 2004).

Foraging occurs primarily on inland marshes, open lakes and reservoirs, and rivers (Knopf and Evans 2004).  Waters range from oligotrophic to eutrophic, muddy to clear; shorelines range from mud or sand to gravel and rock (Knopf and Evans 2004).  Found on large bodies of water in New Mexico including Lake Avalon, Lake McMillan, and the Roswell area (Ligon 1961).  At Bosque del Apache Refuge, recorded as "transient visitor, common" (Ligon 1961).  Islands that are used for breeding are commonly 50+ km from foraging areas (Knopf and Evans 2004).  

Non-breeding habitat, which includes wintering habitats and migratory stopovers, is similar to breeding habitat, except that they appear to depend upon marine estuaries more heavily during winter (Knopf and Evans 2004). This habitat includes open water with surrounding habitats ranging from barren to heavily vegetated sites (BISON-M). Major attractions for migratory birds appear to be large expanses of open water (BISON-M).  Favors shallow coastal bays, inlets, and estuaries with forage fish, exposed loafing sites, and minimum Jan temperatures above 4° C.  Rarely winters at inland habitats, with the Salton Sea being a predictable exception.  When they do winter inland, they use waters below dams or on large rivers where moving flows prevent the surface from freezing.  Sand bars for loafing and roosting appear equally as important as forage availability given that birds discontinue using the Mississippi River once rising water levels inundate bars during spring run-off (Knopf and Evans 2004).  N. Tarr, 2June2010.
